texts.definition: Game elements used to distribute resources, often with different characteristics, without necessarily revealing the distribution.
markups: <style="Definition">Game elements used to distribute resources, often with different characteristics, without necessarily revealing the distribution.</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Tiles</style> are physical game elements used either to distribute resources between players or to mark places on gameplay areas. They may be of many shapes but are typically heavy enough to not be move unless players intentionally mean to move them. They may shared the appearance of one side with other <style="CurrentLink">Tiles</style> to make randomization of them possible, and let game designers choose the exact distribution of each type. <style="CurrentLink">Tiles</style> do not need to be physical game elements; they can also be simulated in computer games.
Note: this pattern shared the same definition as Tiles since the difference primarily concern material and ergonomics.
Note: this pattern does not deal with the tiles that may be used to construct the Chess boards and their like, since these tiles are decorative and cannot themselves be manipulated in games.

The board game <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Othello">Othello</link></style> consists of playing <style="CurrentLink">Tiles</style> and flipping them, trying to make one's color dominant on the board.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/42">42</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mahjong">Mahjong</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Scrabble">Scrabble</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Tien%20Gow">Tien Gow</link></style> are all <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tile-Based%20Games">Tile-Based Games</link></style> where <style="CurrentLink">Tiles</style> are used as resources that form players hands, similar to how cards are used in many <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Card%20Games">Card Games</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Tetris">Tetris</link></style> can also be said to be a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tile-Based%20Games">Tile-Based Games</link></style>.

In contrast, <style="CurrentLink">Tiles</style> are used in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Carcassonne">Carcassonne</link></style> to build game worlds as gameplay progresses while in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Hey!%20That's%20My%20Fish!">Hey! That's My Fish!</link></style> they are used to destroy game worlds as gameplay progresses. The gameplay area of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Settlers%20of%20Catan">Settlers of Catan</link></style> is constructed from <style="CurrentLink">Tiles</style> before gameplay begins, but by randomizing these many different areas are possible. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Carolus%20Magnus">Carolus Magnus</link></style> uses <style="CurrentLink">Tiles</style> to represent gameplay areas also, but here the actual <style="CurrentLink">Tiles</style> have no important information - what affects gameplay is how controls them, if they are joined with other <style="CurrentLink">Tiles</style> to form groups, and their position in relation to other <style="CurrentLink">Tiles</style> and groups. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Small%20World">Small World</link></style> has a fixed board for each number of players but use <style="CurrentLink">Tiles</style> to mark mountains and various constructions that players can create as part of their moves.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NetHack">NetHack</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Slaves%20to%20Armok%20II:%20Dwarf%20Fortress">Slaves to Armok II: Dwarf Fortress</link></style> uses <style="CurrentLink">Tiles</style> to represent corridors, walls, dungeon, and cavern floors and so on. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Minecraft">Minecraft</link></style> does the same although here the <style="CurrentLink">Tiles</style> are actually blocks. These <style="CurrentLink">Tiles</style> are used to generate an almost limitless number of different dungeons but only qualify as <style="CurrentLink">Tiles</style> as they can be destroyed or in some cases moved.

Tiles have many similarities with Cards, so any design intending to use Tiles can also consider using Cards. While both can be used to create Hands of potential actions (e.g. Mahjong and Scrabble uses Tiles in this way) or as Bookkeeping Tokens, Tiles tend to be used to create Game Worlds while Cards instead tend to be used to create Abstract Player Constructs. Usually only one side and one facing of Tiles are used but Othello shows an example where they are flipped to indicate Ownership; American Megafauna turns biome cards to indicate how prevalent the biomes are in regions and Rommel in the Desert turns blocks to indicate the strength of Units.

<style="CurrentLink">Tiles</style> can be used to build <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, and if combined with <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style> can do so before gameplay begins to create entire <style="Link"><link="procedurally-generated-game-worlds">Procedurally Generated Game Worlds</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Tiles</style> used for this can represent <style="Link"><link="environmental-effects">Environmental Effects</link></style> and they can be modified by making them into <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Resource%20Generators">Resource Generators</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="resource-locations">Resource Locations</link></style>, or providing <style="Link"><link="location-fixed-abilities">Location-Fixed Abilities</link></style>. All of these can make the <style="CurrentLink">Tiles</style> into <style="Link"><link="strategic-locations">Strategic Locations</link></style>. A choice when using <style="CurrentLink">Tiles</style> to create <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> like this is if they should be designed so they are "plane-filling" or just represent the important parts of the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>. The former is necessary if <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style> is to be maintained and examples of games with this design solution include <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NetHack">NetHack</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Minecraft">Minecraft</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Settlers%20of%20Catan">Settlers of Catan</link></style>; games that do not this include <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Carolus%20Magnus">Carolus Magnus</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Container">Container</link></style> (although the latter claims that the surface the game is played on represents an ocean).

While <style="Link"><link="tile-laying">Tile-Laying</link></style> can result from <style="CurrentLink">Tiles</style> combined with the <style="Link"><link="construction">Construction</link></style> pattern (e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dominant%20Species">Dominant Species</link></style>), having <style="CurrentLink">Tiles</style> as <style="Link"><link="destructible-objects">Destructible Objects</link></style> instead results in <style="Link"><link="shrinking-game-worlds">Shrinking Game Worlds</link></style> (e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Hey!%20That's%20My%20Fish!">Hey! That's My Fish!</link></style>). Both placing and removing <style="CurrentLink">Tiles</style> are examples of when these become <style="Link"><link="focus-loci">Focus Loci</link></style> for players, but this can also be the case if players can in other ways manipulate them, flipping them as done in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Othello">Othello</link></style> is one example of this. In <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Computer%20Games">Computer Games</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Tiles</style> may have natures that are more dynamic. In the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Super%20Mario%20series">Super Mario series</link></style> there are several examples of <style="CurrentLink">Tiles</style> that start to deteriorate when stepped on, creating <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style> for long the tile can be used. In <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Greed%20Corp">Greed Corp</link></style> each turn a harvester is used next to a hex or on it while remove one layer of it and finally remove the <style="CurrentLink">Tile</style> altogether.

Like <style="Link"><link="cards">Cards</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Tiles</style> can be used for <style="Link"><link="trick-taking">Trick Taking</link></style> and is in this case often combined with <style="Link"><link="turn-taking">Turn Taking</link></style>. These, and games where <style="CurrentLink">Tiles</style> are picked by players and then played (e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Carcassonne">Carcassonne</link></style>), often place the <style="CurrentLink">Tiles</style> in <style="Link"><link="drawing-stacks">Drawing Stacks</link></style>. Used <style="CurrentLink">Tiles</style> can be placed in <style="Link"><link="discard-piles">Discard Piles</link></style> and the distribution of <style="CurrentLink">Tiles</style> in <style="Link"><link="drawing-stacks">Drawing Stacks</link></style> can be manipulated by <style="Link"><link="stack-seeding">Stack Seeding</link></style>.

As <style="CurrentLink">Tiles</style> can be the building blocks of <style="Link"><link="game-boards">Game Boards</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style>, they can be important in maintaining a game's <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Tiles</style> can construct <style="Link"><link="game-boards">Game Boards</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style>, and allow these to be separated into clearly distinguishable areas, making the position and possibilities of actions easier to judge. This also allow easier changes in them, either in ownership if they represent <style="Link"><link="territories">Territories</link></style> or in the actual gameplay area; the latter is in many cases used to have <style="Link"><link="reconfigurable-game-worlds">Reconfigurable Game Worlds</link></style> (e.g. to create <style="Link"><link="shrinking-game-worlds">Shrinking Game Worlds</link></style>). They also make it easy to have <style="Link"><link="configurable-gameplay-areas">Configurable Gameplay Areas</link></style> before gameplay begins (e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Settlers%20of%20Catan">Settlers of Catan</link></style>).

Besides being used to create <style="Link"><link="game-boards">Game Boards</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Tiles</style> can like <style="Link"><link="cards">Cards</link></style> form <style="Link"><link="sets">Sets</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="abstract-player-constructs">Abstract Player Constructs</link></style>. Being able to add <style="CurrentLink">Tiles</style> to <style="Link"><link="abstract-player-constructs">Abstract Player Constructs</link></style> make <style="Link"><link="abstract-player-construct-development">Abstract Player Construct Development</link></style> possible while being able to add <style="CurrentLink">Tiles</style> in other gameplay is often some sort of <style="Link"><link="construction">Construction</link></style> activity.

When <style="CurrentLink">Tiles</style> need to be given to players during gameplay, they can support both <style="Link"><link="drawing-stacks">Drawing Stacks</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="drafting">Drafting</link></style> and through shuffling them <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style>. With fixed distributions of which types of <style="CurrentLink">Tiles</style> exist, these design solutions encourage players to engage in <style="Link"><link="memorizing">Memorizing</link></style> which <style="CurrentLink">Tiles</style> have been drawn and which have been played.

<style="Link"><link="abstract-player-constructs">Abstract Player Constructs</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="bookkeeping-tokens">Bookkeeping Tokens</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="configurable-gameplay-areas">Configurable Gameplay Areas</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="construction">Construction</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="drafting">Drafting</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="drawing-stacks">Drawing Stacks</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="environmental-effects">Environmental Effects</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="focus-loci">Focus Loci</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-boards">Game Boards</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="memorizing">Memorizing</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="reconfigurable-game-worlds">Reconfigurable Game Worlds</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="sets">Sets</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="strategic-locations">Strategic Locations</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="territories">Territories</link></style>
